commentBody: Somebody--not me, I don't ever see it--is going to complain that they saw the column's picture below their puzzle while solving, and that it is a spoiler.
This one was definitely not for me

I can't make my own oleo. But I'll get butter at it.

(If only margarinely so.)

Now that was a Saturday puzzle.

Thank you, Byron!

A 23.12
TW 19.18
B 10.57

6033 puzzles solved
100% solve rate
758 current streak 
758 longest streak
After thinking I was so smart all week‚Ä¶ with this one I needed the clues.

What a great puzzle.

If I recall correctly, one of Byron‚Äôs former college students once posted a very nice note about him on here.  Every time I do one of his puzzles, I feel like I am learning something new while having a great, and often pleasurably vexing, time.  I have no doubt that he is an excellent math professor, and luckily for us, an excellent crossword constructor to boot.
Oof, GALOIS/OCELO/LEA is one hell of a Natick. I knew Lea, fortunately, but had it spelled Lia. Tried the other spelling for my Gold Star. Tough solve. 33 minutes even

I thought this one was going to do me in.  Not in my wheelhouse at all. I‚Äôm happy to have wrenched a solve out of it bit by bit.  HEXER was a vexer. the L in LEASALONGA and GALOIS, with both of whom I was not familiar, was the last piece to fall.  Like Proust‚Äôs madeleine, this one conjured up that long lost feeling from when I first solved a Saturday with no look ups.

42A is THOS? Really? Is that some archaic British English spelling? 

THOM or TOM, or even TOMMY are the short forms of Thomas.
Bart Simpson is not a superhero.
I failed the trivia contest.

I‚Äôm tickled to get this one without help - especially since the SW was almost blank with the rest completed. I even dug GALOIS out of my mathematical memory. But OCELA (never heard of it) crossing LEASALONGO (never heard of her) about did me in. Crunch crunch crunch eventually I just had to guess a vowel or too. This was fun!

One of the best Saturday puzzles in some time.  It trusts its solvers to be well read and reasonably intelligent. 

Nice to see the sublime LEASALONGA in there. And a reference to differential GALOIS theory? Wonderful!

More like this, please. Saturdays have been a bit too easy lately.

I adore crosswords that keep me on the edge of my seat -- will I be able to solve it? or will my streak go up in flames? -- but end up being (just, barely) solvable. Then, I get to spend 30 minutes looking up facts, listening to music, etc., to get the 411 on what I didn't know. That combination of challenge and learning is just perfect, and never gets old. Thanks, Byron, for a perfect Saturday!

[P.S. Our daily, ad-free, chuckle-rich podcast, Jean & Mike Do The New York Times Crossword, is still going strong, and we love new listeners!]

Ouch. 

Had to look up so much of the trivia (at least I knew Lea Salonga) and had way too many errors (BLue for BLOB, Else for ERGO, witch for HEXER even though that made me grumble, PRESSreAdy for PRESSSTART) and incompletes (THO_ I couldn't remember if it was S or m, the ASL clue had two options, etc) to be fun. 

(I'm not saying it's a bad puzzle, just not my wavelength and not an enjoyable experience.)
How do people solve ones like this? I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôll ever get a Saturday.

I‚Äôve pretty well managed to UNLEARN what all I used to know about GALOIS theory.
Yeah, it used to feature SEVEN HOUR take home exams, with an UNWAVERING sense of impending doom.
Still, here he shows up in the puzzle, so I guess I remember something.

Fun puzzle! But Ash Carter deserved more than to be called trivia. Please read his remarks on the decision to include transgender people in the military. A wisdom we are now lacking. https://www.defense.gov/News/Speeches/Speech/Article/821833/remarks-on-ending-the-ban-on-transgender-service-in-the-us-military/

Friends, I'm not sure I'm going to make it. 

After many recent puzzles where I have broken my own records by astonishing times,  this one may be the end of me and all I hold dear.

If you never hear from me again, please know I hold you in highest regard and that I've enjoyed our time together... Please don't forget me. And please tell my husband I love him. 

All right, cracking my knuckles, doing a couple back stretches, and I'm going back in!!
Was hoping to get a challenging Saturday and this one definitely delivered. Took almost an hour out of my Saturday morning but enjoyed every minute of it. More of these please.
phew. my streak survived and I'm proud of getting this gold star.

All those 10, 9, and 8-letter entries made for a TIGHT FIT, very little glue required.  Now that‚Äôs the sign of a master craftsman!

Favorite entry‚Ä¶.AUSTENITES.  Proud to be one. 

Great clue "Bond classification" for ACTION HERO. 

Well done, Byron.

It's funny how crosswords some people find challenging others breeze right through. I had no trouble with today's puzzle; however, yesterday's knocked me for a loop, even though it seemed many commenters found it too easy for a Friday. I enjoyed myself both days, but perhaps a bit more yesterday; there's nothing like the sense of accomplishment you get from finishing a puzzle that really had you tied up in knots!

Despite the touching (and true!) constructor note, the clue for GALOIS is not good. "Differential Galois Theory" is a real thing, but it's not the theory for which Galois is best-known by a long shot - "Galois theory" is a much more common term. "For whom an algebraic theory is named" would be much more appropriate.

I'm always asking for more math in the crossword, but that won't stop me from posting things like this xP
Back to my old tricks. After losing my streak yesterday, I used autocheck in frustration after only 10 minutes. Well, at least I can go to bed earlier now. Sigh.

I am going to stick my neck out for a moment. A student of Austen, an expert on Austen, an avid reader of Austen‚Äîmay all be Austenites. But a true lover of Aunt Jane like myself is and always will be a Janeite. That‚Äôs my hill and I‚Äôm going to die on it.

Mr. Walden, if you're reading this, I came here today to say, first and foremost, thank you for a really rich puzzle, with entrances into many a rabbit hole. 
My synapses were crazy firing and you've given me lots of homework.

I'd also like to say that, despite having been an A+ algebra student in high-school,  I understood nothing of your constructor notes until you got to "His so-called Galois theory laid the foundation for algebra as it is studied today."
But I sure guffawed all the way through that first part, so thank you for that, too!

Mr. Byron Walden, your puzzles never disappoint and always live up to your very inspired name.üôåüèª

I have made one spin through this puzzle, both across and down, and have only a few tentative fills. Came here to see if people were calling this one easy, because that might be the sign to throw in the towel. Is it better that I‚Äôm not the only one having problems? I don‚Äôt know, but this may be the one that breaks me. 

Good luck, everyone else. Hope to see you on the other side. Don‚Äôt wait up.

I kept hoping for that golden moment of enlightenment, when I suddenly get rolling and everything becomes clear.  Uh, not this time. A slog all the way. Not unpleasant (actually enjoyable) but I thought I'd never get it done.  

Thank you, Byron Walden. for a puzzle worthy of a Saturday.  No kidding around, just got us thinking and learning things, like that smart boy's name, and who did the animation singing, and that the Rhodes Scholars won't be crowded. My admiration for your creativity is UNWAVERING.

I‚Äôm calling Natick. 24A and 26D are beyond the limits of reasonable knowledge for mere mortals. Throw in the unknown 37A and the highly suspicious 38D, and there you have it. It qualifies. 

There are those who will disagree with me. You‚Äôre entitled to your opinion, as am I.

Wow! What an amazing Saturday workout! I‚Äôm not ashamed to say the SW corner finally did me in, and I haven‚Äôt been done in by a NYT puzzle in a long time. I did get LEASALONGA although this bit of trivia was new to me. I made an educated guess on BOARDIES which panned out. I had ELSE (thinking of computer logic) before ERGO for a long time, and I couldn‚Äôt get my head around RESTON for the literal meaning of surmount for awhile, but got there too eventually. But I couldn‚Äôt get past ITS instead of TIS, and had CEELO in my head instead of OCELO, so I was left with ACAIBUTTER which I was skeptical of as a dairy product but couldn‚Äôt get around. And despite what I thought was a decent background in math and AP calculus, GALOIS was a total unknown to me. And only just this second did I figure out that ACTIONHERO meant James Bond and not some funky nickname for a well-performing investment. So I finally succumbed and looked up CEELO to find out while he did write a SpongeBob song he is not a brand of sponge.
Well done! I am thrilled to have been pummeled into submission by a fiendish but ultimately fair challenge and look forward to many more.

Solid Saturday. The trivia wasn‚Äôt exactly in my wheelhouse, but I managed to puzzle it out. Funny enough, the last square to fall was #1. I had a G there, convinced it was something to do with a glow up‚Äîeven though glow dry made zero sense. Glob seemed reasonable, too. Eventually, I figured out my mistake.

As a proud bald person, ignorance is baldness‚Äîat least when it comes to hair-related terms.
Some trivia made me go to Google, French mathematicians being not my forte. 4D I would have thought it should be floundered not foundered but didn‚Äôt spoil a very enjoyable puzzle

Byron Walden is a master. Really, what else is there to say?

Thank you for the Saturday puzzle I‚Äôve been waiting for, Byron.

Not looking at any hints, and I've come here mid-solve, which I never do...

But this puzzle is KMA (abbr).

Maybe it's fatigue from trying to outlast my five-year-old granddaughter's play instinct.  Maybe I'm just too "old-man-away-from-home-out-of-sorts", but this is a throwback to the days when a Saturday was at best quarter filled, most of which is wrong.

I very much doubt I'll ever come through with this one.

So I won't read the comments on how easy it was.

PDA 

Anyone willing to elucidate please?

Oh man. 

I don‚Äôt know what is worse. 
Failing to get a section, so a lot of blank squares. 

Or 

Two squares that I couldn‚Äôt figure out and finally did ‚Äúcheck puzzle‚Äù after grinding for so long. 
I just couldn‚Äôt crack ASHCA__ER and its crosses M_LONELY and SI_ES. 

I couldn‚Äôt let go of soLONELY or imLONELY. But that M in the front. It had to be MeLONELY or MyLONELY, right?  Right? Right?  It never ever occurred to me that it would be MR. Even after ‚Äúcheck puzzle.‚Äù  All I could come up with was Ms. 

Then I played the alphabet game with ASHCAe_ER or ASHCAy_ER. I just couldn‚Äôt crack it. Maddening.  

Anyway. It was ‚ÄúSaturday tough‚Äù. Maybe too much proper noun for my taste. But that is also what made it hard, I guess. 

Looking back. I‚Äôm lucky I got the French math guy and voice actress cross. I remembered, kinda, Ms Salonga‚Äôs name from Miss Saigon, which was a city colonized by a French mathematician who had thing for Bahn Mi.

So, so many clues I had no idea about. From LEASA LONGA and all the surrounding clues, to ASH and that nearby corner, to REB AND AMER. Ooooh, hard!

You win some .....

Really really didn't enjoy this one. The punny clues were particularly helpful and worse than that, weren't particularly funny. A lot of unrecognizable words that really had me second guessing my answers, but not in a fun or exciting way. What are boardies?? No one says that.

I think the complaints about the GALOIS LEA SALONGA crossing are partially valid, but to me, the L in GALOIS is guessable, and the most likely letter to form two sensible looking names.

But maybe that's because my father, a proud Welshman, used to wear a T-shirt on holidays to France which read: "Suis pas Anglais, je suis Gallois."

And on the same holidays, I used to sing along to "A Whole New World" with my sister, doing our best impressions of Brad Kane and LEA SALONGA.
Love it - knew it would be a proper test from the moment I saw the byline. Loads of stuff I didn't know, but I got there. Knowing Lea Salonga was a stroke of luck.

This crossword got me angry and irritated. This activity is supposed to be fun and challenging, but not to the level that the challenge is too hard and then no fun is left. Real life provides enough quota of frustration and irritation. I do not need my recreation to evoke the same feelings. Really bad.

First heard of Galois theory while watching a documentary on the proof of Fermat's Last Theorem.

There was a point when it seemed this puzzle would take four hundred years to complete.

Yikes!  This gave me a run for my money.  What a perfect old-fashioned Saturday puzzle.  A final guess at the end pulled me through even though, technically, I was wrong.  I decided the most logical name had to be an unconventional spelling of Lisa, and there was someone out there named LEASA LONGA.

More made-up entries than in any puzzle I've seen. Does anyone actually say HEYANYBODY? Is BESTADVICE even a thing? YOU'VE is not a particularly natural entry to "changed". BUTI is too lame even for fill. It's more like the answers were dreamed up to suit the clues than the other way around. 

And to surmount something doesn't mean to RESTON it. That's what you do after you have surmounted it. I avoided putting that in for the longest time because I knew it simply wasn't correct. 

Didnt finish and am not the least bit bothered by that.

Oh. My. Lord.
I see Mr Walden‚Äôs name, I know I‚Äôm in for a slog. How does one person put together such impossible clues, but have a whole that fits beautifully and makes complete sense?? If my head hadn‚Äôt exploded I would tip my hat to you sir.

Let‚Äôs start with Mr Walden‚Äôs constructor notes; I‚Äôve said before here that I am dyscalculic. Maths is the equivalent of the 7th circle of hell for me. I, literally, with no hyperbole, did not understand a single word other than it was a young Frenchman, his name and the fact he died aged 20 after a duel. Mon Dieu, tres Francais.  So there‚Äôs that.

Naturally I had no clue what 13D meant. Eventually got it with crosses but still needed to really look at it.

The singer. Nope. Dance. Nope. Which MARIO? Nope. Scrubbers? Nope. Song. Nope. 

BUT; I knew BLOW DRY BAR which helped. Never been in one. That‚Äôs a thing for them big cities. Haven‚Äôt reached Somerset yet.
I knew the French Assembly was LOWER HOUSE, ERGO the Mexican chamber must be the same. Figured out 17A. Am I the only one to find that cringingly icky?

The rest was the proverbial slog of trying to fit letters in to make a sensible word. And yet, once finished, with a few exceptions (see above), it was all so obvious. Now THAT‚Äôs a Saturday puzzle. Bravo.

Often get the feeling that many here assign a ceiling to the time spent on these puzzles, then just plain quit when they hit that limit.  Too hard!  Unfair!  Bad clues!

This one took 30min more than average, but it finally yielded after a healthy (unhealthy?) amount of hair pulling and foul language.  Maybe that's the benefit of being retired -- or starting at 4 AM!
The logical answer is Austen Fans and not Austenites.  This puzzle should have been rejected, not published.

This was a brutal puzzle. Ever since I neared a milestone I've been fearful that I will come across something like this that will end the run.  Happy to say that I persisted, but Byron definitely made me earn that 1000 crossword streak!
Not a fan. I enjoy a tough puzzle, but this was neither a fair test nor a fun challenge. Far too much obscure trivia. Ruined some of the otherwise clever clueing.
So much complaining in the comments. I enjoyed this puzzle thoroughly. Maybe I was just lucky? I look forward to more Saturday puzzles from this author.

This was a tough Saturday and, as others have said, it was a bit on the Jeopardy! side as opposed to the wordplay side. 

I came here to say that looking things up online (as facts, not as crossword clues) is not in my view cheating.
Once again, woof. Made it through but it was a slog. My fuzzy brain thanks you for the challenge!
This was one of the most brutal puzzles I've seen in a while. I've been getting progressively better at not using Google for help, but today was extremely tricky.

I got so excited when I saw Byron Walden's name on this puzzle. Finally, finally, harkening back to the good ol' days, when puzzles were real puzzlers. I thought Will must have had a change of heart and decided to part with some of the NYT's big bucks, this being Byron's 109th puzzle for the Times. 

Then I started to work on the puzzle, which elicited the expression "Be careful what you wish for." It was tough! But wonderful! No rap artists, no real sports clues, just arcana like Gaulois. 

Like Caitlin, I started from the  very easy SE corner and worked my way up. Well, almost up. I was left with the middle. Fer cryin' out loud, I cut my young teenage teeth on Bobby Vinton and couldn't remember the first two letters of LONELY, even though every other word of the song was playing in my head. Ultimately, I was forced to look up ASH CARTER, and that first R gave my brain the jolt it needed to remember that it was MR LONELY. One and done. 

Byron, thanks for the workout. And more of these, please.  I can think of a whole bunch of erstwhile constructors I'd like to see back on these pages, along with Robyn Weintraub.
Tougher than average for me, but I did know GALOIS for starters!

A Walden Saturday feels like a holiday to me ‚Äì and it‚Äôs been more than a year since it‚Äôs come around. 

You don‚Äôt simply enter the box in a Walden puzzle.  It‚Äôs more like going to another country.  It has its own distinct feel.  And I‚Äôm a fan of that feel.  Byron takes no prisoners.  He brings me to the edge of uncle, and man, it feels like a victory to enter practically every square. It‚Äôs a magnificent solve riddled with victories.

Today: A 66-word, 21 block elegant grid (both these numbers ridiculously low), squeaky clean.  Okay, there‚Äôs THOS, but it‚Äôs easily saved by a terrific factoid clue.  Try filling a 66/21 grid, even ugly, and you will bow with respect at Byron‚Äôs talent.

Two things you can count on in Waldenstan:
‚Ä¢	Fabulous original wordplay clues, like today‚Äôs [Smack in the middle of a crowd, in brief?] for PDA, and [Curve that‚Äôs high and outside?] for ARCH. Two bland answers given shimmer through wit.
‚Ä¢	Debut Times puzzle answers ‚Äì 19! Nineteen!  I did the math, and three-quarters of the squares with letters belong to debut answers (.738%)!  Did your puzzle feel vibrant?  Welcome to Waldenstan.  My favorite debuts were TIGHT FIT, UNWAVERING, ROSE TO FAME, PRESS START, and the marvelous HEY ANYBODY.

Byron, you are such a credit to Crosslandia. Your puzzles sizzle. What a beaut you brought today.  Thank you sir!

I didn't understand any part of the first two-thirds of Byron's explanation regarding Galois. Higher math and I are like oil and water.

I was great in arithmetic in grade school, but when I got to JHS and had to take algebra, my eyes glazed over. Pulled through by the skin of my teeth and tutoring by the good-looking older boy next door. Then in HS it only got worse. I was on the verge of failing geometry when my teacher, Mr. Seinberg, made a deal with me: he'd pass me in geometry if I swore I'd never take another math class. Of course I agreed; I hated math. 

And then I found out that the college I wanted to attend had just put in a rule that trigonometry would be needed for acceptance. I had to go back to Mr. Seinberg with my tail between my legs and beg him to let me take trig. He made me audit it the first semester before taking it for credit during the second. It didn't end well. I did get into that college, but had to take it again there. I finally passed, and went on to my preferred course of study - languages.

This one gave me the Saturday experience I look for---a real workout, with occasional moments of despair.

Solved it unaided, but took almost 45 minutes. Eventually remembering  ASHCARTER and knowing OCELO proved very helpful. Other than HEXER, which made me wince, the fill seemed extremely solid.

As a mathematician, GALOIS was a gimme, though the clue struck me as a bit wonky. 

All in all, an excellent Saturday puzzle. More like this, please!
By-ron, I think he‚Äôs got it!

Broke a streak on this.  Missed galois.    Spent 68 minutes on it so killed my average as well.   

Fun puzzle but too many things I didn't know.
Had to look up the singer. I really liked the look of Gia crossing with Gogol (yeah not French, whatever) but that went nowhere. That whole lower west side was a nightmare. Great Saturday!

Nineteen debut answers - three others making their first appearance in a Shortz era puzzle. Don't recall ever seeing anything quite like that before. Anyway... well above my pay grade; was stuck in multiple places. No big deal. Puzzle find today: A Sunday from November 3, 1991 by the great Maura B. Jacobson with the title "International double plays." Theme answers in that one: CROATOMANICOLORS DONTKHMERANYMOOR IWENTGAULFINN GRANDKENYANSWEDE SERBTHEMAYANDISH CZECHKURDPATTERN CANTTHAIMEDEDOWN That's amazing. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=11/3/1991&g=16&d=D ....

I can in truth say that took longer than Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday put together.

If I can somehow get tomorrow done in a PB, it might turn out to have taken longer than the rest of the week.

Wow, this was a worthy Saturday puzzle. Tough, chewy, crunchy; had to walk away and come back to it a coupla times. Finally finished but had to google-verify the Disney princess and comics superhero trivia. Everybody, if you can, do the Bartman. Oh, yeah! Shake your body, turn it out if you can, man. Shake yo' body! Front to the back, to the side if you can, can. Huh! Everybody in the house do the Bartman. Yeah, do the Bartman. Everybody, if you can, do the Bartman. Everybody, yeah, do the Bartman. Shake your body, turn it out if you can, man. Shake it out. Front to the back, to the side if you can, can. Whoa, mama. Everybody in the house do the Bartman. I'm bad, I'm bad! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xc8foK41qmo

Pretty hard for me but not a killer.  I was way too tired when I started.  This morning both Lea Salonga and the "Mr." in Bobby's ballad popped right into my head, and let me clean up the mess I'd made of the left side.  So the logical connector is NOT ELSE after all.  The shorts wear does NOT have "undies" in it.  And the bond classification just turns out to be sort of boring.  Before that, running the alphabet to figure the X for the awkward fill for magic practitioner helped.

Decent, challenging puzzle.  Surely "hey anybody" is the weakest of the answers.
That's it.  From now on, I am doing the Saturday crossword first, and saving Connections and Wordle to assuage my deflated puzzler ego!
Woof. The only answer I got without looking anything up to get a toehold was austenites.

I enjoyed this one a lot.  Lots of new trivia for me.
I have never heard the words ‚ÄúBOARDIES‚Äù or ‚ÄúOCELO‚Äù before, and I have a math degree and have never heard of ‚ÄúGALOIS‚Äù. I also have never heard of a ‚ÄúBLOW OUT BAR‚Äù, I‚Äôll have to look that one up.
testing
One of the best constructor notes ever!

Great workout! First pass left a ton of blank space, but like others the SE cracked for me first, in spite of, like a dolt, confusing Bronte and Austen.  I also thought the dance craze was related to Superman, but just having THE....MAN helped me fix that corner and work my way out. 

I did have to do the one lookup for ASHCARTER because I could only think of IM or SO for the song and that was getting me nowhere. 

Still, one lookup for a Saturday especially given what I'm seeing about this constructor feels like an achievement!

I'm sorry, but this is an awful Sat puzzle. What a slog!
Please don't refer to it as a "worthy challenge". It is beyond broken. It's funny because the right half and most of the center is balanced - perfect Sat difficulty level and lacks the awful slang and random PPP.

1A- can the setters just get serious for once? I don't care if this is a real thing. Couple of unfriendly downs to top it off.

24A/26D - R.P. should rename Natick for this atrocity. Random purposeless trivia.
P.S. - Thanks for including 28 & 37A with these.
The Bartman? Serious natick. Too many naticks.
Tough puzzle for me. Left side came pretty easily. Had to look up some names. Great way to start a Saturday. Thanks!

At first I didn't like it - had to look up some answers.  But after I cheated a few times, it got to be more fun.  Took some time but I felt a nice sense accomplishment when I entered the last correct square.  The cluing was especially difficult for me, but I admired its originality and cleverness.
Very hard. The top part came to me relatively easily but the rest was brutal. True Saturday challenge

I must take issue with the answer for 1D. The by-the-wind sailor, aka velella velella, is anything but a BLOB. It has a highly structured body with a hard chitin-like ‚Äúsail‚Äù that is used to propel it across the ocean surface. I've encountered these creatures many times along Ocean Beach in San Francisco and am always amazed at their neon blue coloration.

Blob indeed!

Wow! Those long spans are always daunting, and they didn't necessarily fill in easily. I felt pretty good to come within a minute of my Saturday average (plus a few seconds).

The fact that it's almost 8:00 and barely 100 comments suggests that others found it challenging, too.

Lots of trivia (or just plain facts) that I had no idea of, but nothing that couldn't be deduced eventually.

For 13D I started out trying to put STATE at the end. For 43A I just figured it was probably [something]MAN. For 21A  I was the opposite of UNWAVERING, vacillating between CREE and Otoe.

Eventually the unconquered territory began to recede, with the southwest remaining a challenge. Never heard of LEASALONGA  (which I mentally parsed as LEASA LONGA) or GALOIS, but it was deleting a whole lot, especially swapping else for ERGO, that did it.

Great puzzle!!

Great Saturday puzzle!  Crunchy and fresh.  The combo we're all looking for (if we're true crossword lovers).

Things I didn't know in today's puzzle:
GALOIS  (hat tip to those who thought this was a gimme, or were concerned that the clue was imprecise)
BLOW-DRY BAR (Really? That's a thing?? I remember learning about dry shampoo in a spray can and thinking...  Is this similar?)
BOARDIES  (I've heard of baggies, but now that means something else.
ASH CARTER  (After I had ASH-, I was sure it had to be ASHCroft, even though I thought [correctly] that he was a Republican.  When it didn't fit I tried to give him a double-T or double-F.)
LEA SALONGA (Broadway musicals have never been my thing, and Disney musicals are even worse IMHO.)
"by-the-wind sailor" (Had anyone heard of this before?)

But I bravely (!) fought through these difficulties.
Thanks for the challenge, Byron Walden!
Bart Simpson is a superhero?
1D was a poor clue, but Galois (and the constructor notes) made up for it. I've taught AP Calculus, but the name was still unfamiliar to me. "The Bartman" brought a smile of nostalgia.

I had fun! Never heard of a BLOWDRYBAR, BOARDIES, and even GOATBUTTER came as a surprise, but the crosses were doable. 
Read the clue for 14D and immediately thought HEYANYBODY - and by gosh it was right! Love when that happens. 
Happy Saturday!
Just because you CAN use a word/term....doesn't mean you SHOULD. What a slog...and as such, not fun at all.
10:27 in and frankly I‚Äôm already concerned.

Loved it. Barely anything on my first pass but it slowly came together for me. ASH CARTER / MR LONELY area was the last to go for me - I was stuck for too long on the concept of SO LONELY or IM LONELY. Didn‚Äôt know GALOIS / OCELO but guessed based on French phonology and then LEA SALONGA dredged herself up from the depths of my memory into vague recognition. 

This is the kind of satisfying Saturday solve I‚Äôm looking for! #MakeSaturdaysHardAgain
Disney princesses and pop singers are definitely not in my wheelhouse, but Celine Dion made perfect sense, and it fit.

One more puzzle find. NEVER seen another one like this. A Sunday from June 2, 2013 by Elizabeth C. Gorski with the title: "Stir crazy." The 'reveal' in that one was: "Alice Walker novel ... or a hint to 12 squares in this puzzle" THECOLORPURPLE And those 12 squares were a rebus, but... for the down answer the rebus was 'RED' and for the across answer the rebus was 'BLUE' A couple of examples of the crossings: ER(RED) - down answer TALKEDA(BLUE)STREAK - across answer (RED)EEM - down answer (BLUE)INTHEFACE - across answer FAVO(RED) down answer (BLUE)BOOK - across answer SH(RED)S - down answer DRESS(BLUE)S - across answer Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/2/2013&g=116&d=A ....

Normally, my complaints tend to be focused on the US-centric answers which make it particularly challenging for a brit like me (but NYT is a US publication so that's understandable). Not in this case.

Ok, here‚Äôs my last word on Naticks for today. If by Natick you mean crossing words that a certain high percentage of solvers don‚Äôt already know, then GALOIS and LEASALONGA and maybe BOARDIES and OCELO are Naticks. But the real question should be (at least if you are going to complain about them) is whether an intellectually curious person should or would want know them? With the exception of OCELO I think that‚Äôs the case. I‚Äôm happy to learn that surfers wear board shorts and they are called BOARDIES. If I didn‚Äôt know who LEA SALONGA was I would be excited to look her up and learn about her accomplishments, which certainly go far beyond Disney movies. And I‚Äôm tickled to learn that despite a decent math background and more than my share of math lectures on the Great Lectures series, there‚Äôs an important mathematician I haven‚Äôt heard of and I‚Äôm grateful for the constructor explaining his work to me. Folks, are we here just to prove how smart we already are or can we set a secondary goal for ourselves to grow and learn?

I like a difficult puzzle, but I think this one was difficult for the wrong reasons. I love those clever and devious clues that when you figure out the answer you appreciate the guile and lateral thinking and how brilliantly it was clued. Another way to make a puzzle difficult is to fill it with obscure (to most) references, clues that don‚Äôt quite work, questionable fill. and green paint. To some, I guess this is what makes a fun puzzle, but not for me. chacun √† son go√ªt.

Green paint (multi-word answers that aren‚Äôt common phrases) are my personal puzzle peeve, and there was no shortage of these today: (HEYANYBODY, SEVENHOUR, OPENMOUTHS, PRESSSTART, BESTADVICE, BUTI[disagree], and more). In the category of obscure fill, a certain amount in a late-week puzzle is fine, expected even, but too much is just a way to make a puzzle difficult without making it interesting, clever, or fun. In today‚Äôs puzzle I think the line may have been crossed. Some examples from today‚Äôs puzzle (some of which I knew) there were: GALOIS, MRLONELY, OCELO, THOS, THEBARTMAN, LEASALONGA. Some of these (like MRLONELY) were derivable after getting enough letters.   I‚Äôd put HEXER into the bad fill category, but one or two in a puzzle is generally just an annoyance. 

This puzzle also had some lovely clues like ‚ÄúBond Classification‚Äù , but not nearly enough for me üò¢.

It was clued as a horse color, but it‚Äôs not a color, it‚Äôs a pattern and the pattern color varies from horse to horse. So here is my problem with a true Natick like 24A/26D (in response to @SP and other commenters):

I do enjoy learning about people like Evariste GALOIS. (Animated movie actresses, not so much, but YMMV).

But I want to learn about them from the crossings. 

And that‚Äôs precisely what a Natick *doesn‚Äôt* let me do.

PS ‚Äî A brief primer on Naticks. 

BOARDIES crossing OCELO is not a Natick in my book. ‚ÄúBoard shorts‚Äù are fairly common, and BOARDIES is both a Saturday-appropriate slang term (in terms of usage) and one that is eminently guessable from the generous clue and a couple of crosses. Even if you don‚Äôt know LEAS_LONGA, what else could BO_RDIES be? 

With GA_OIS crossing _EASALONGA, in contrast, knowing both are names, there are lots and lots of possibilities ‚Äî including most of the consonants. 

Not the end of the world. But worth a comment (at least in my book).

If we knew nothing whatever about Jane Austen, the novels would be enough.  They are love stories, love felt for family as much as unfolding love for a potential partner, told with clear insight into the difference between what people seem to be and what they are, the ridiculousness of snobbery, the precariousness of life without money, and always, the reliability of integrity.  

What has made the novels endure is that she tells these stories with a delicious kind of humor, a sure eye for the silliness of self-importance and the value of honesty, all revealed through the dilemmas she creates in the stories she tells.  

When we admire an artist there is an urge to have more, to pull aside the curtain and find out everything about the wizard. but it's the art that counts.  We should accept that there isn't any more, and the books she has given us are enough.
